p: The experience accumulated from agroecological initiatives in thousands of small-and-medium scale farms are critical in the definition of Cuban national policies to support sustainable agriculture. However, in what is known as the ‘Cuban agriculture paradox’, Cuba still imports substantial amounts of food and uses, posing the question of the efficiency of the sustainable programs [ 55, 69]. Policy makers seem to support conventional agriculture when the financial situation improves, while sustainable approaches and agroecology are considered alternatives, only supported under scenarios of economic scarcity.
